text:
Welcome to
'This is My Architecture' New Zealand.
I'm Viral from AWS.

And joining me today,
I have Kris from Vodafone New Zealand.
Welcome, Kris.
Thanks, Viral for having me.

Kris, why don't we start off
by you telling us a little bit

about Vodafone New Zealand
and your journey to here?

Thanks. So early 2020,
we started on a migration journey

from existing on-prem legacy
contact center solution into AWS.

Our existing solutions suffered
from a number of drawbacks.
Number one, the complexity of the solution

ended up meaning that
we had to keep adding to it.
It was very costly and expensive to change

and that then drove complexity
back into the application.

And in the end,
by the time we decided to migrate,

the solution itself consisted of over 
81,000 different ways

that a customer can interact
with our services and products.
That's a huge number.

Additionally to that, we had no visibility of
what customers were doing inside our IVR,
so we couldn't change it.
We couldn't be informed about how that change

would actually affect our customers.
Migrating to the cloud,
we had to rethink how that could be changed

and how we could support
that in the AWS landscape.

Kris, could you tell us
a little bit about the scale,
how many agents, how many calls?

So that solution,
the existing solution supported

over 2,500 agents
over three different geographic locations,

and handled
over 1 million phone calls per month.

That is a really large scale and a
great opportunity for transformation,
81,000 pathways for a customer.
That's some serious complexity.
How did Connect help?

So Connect obviously was our core
to our solution

and us lifting and shifting our
existing on-prem solution into Connect
wasn't going to give us anything,

it was just going
to move the complexity into the cloud.

So by using Connect and Lex, we're able
to simplify the way

that customers actually interacted with our IVR
and our solution, both for chat and voice.

Lex, when we started building our intents
and matching in it,
only consisted of 200 intents.

So you can imagine going from 81,000
different ways of navigating through our product
to only 200 ways of, both asking for

and requesting service to other products,
billing, sales, etc. And it's a huge change.

So immediately we've already
simplified landscape a little bit.

Secondly, Connect,
we didn't really want to go off

and start building contact flows
from day one, just concrete flows,
every use case was a flow.
We decided to, instead of doing that,

move to more of a universal
contact flow which is modular

and they would be stitched together
through configuration supplied
by both Lex, Lambda, and DynamoDB.

That gave us the ability then
to externalize a lot of stitching
and mapping out to an external source
and drive those contact flows as we need to.

Awesome, so you've spoken about
the transformation, simplicity,

and you've also spoken
to a little bit around automation.

I see Terraform there,
I see Developers, I see Dev Tools and Connect.

Can you talk us
through how that all comes together?

Sure, so the existing old solution
that we were going from very hard to change,
impossible to test and when we changed it,
we didn't know we were going to break anything.

We have to radically change that to
get comfort in the business to iterate fast

and get that continuous information feedback
so we could change things
and know that they're not going to break,
and our customers wouldn't be affected.

To start with that, our developers
interacted with our Dev Tools
and use Terraform using infrastructure as code
to automatically promote both Connect flows,

Lex intents, Lambda and DynamoDB
as well as other AWS services

into our environment
in a no-touch and automated tested pipeline.

It's awesome to see how agility
has been wrapped into the solution.
So we've got simplification, we've got agility.
Talk to us about the data.

Sure. I mean Connect itself
pumps out a lot of data

and with Contact Lens
we're getting sent to analysis,

we're getting automatic transcription
as well as we're getting the CTR attributes,

we're getting contact flow logs
and all this data together

is being pumped out
to our Snowflake data warehouse
where we also have a single view of customer.

With this information we're able to then
service it up through dashboards, where agents,

team leads, and developers are able to query
the information and understand

how customers are actually interacting
with our products.

And critically, the developers are able
to be informed about how changes are made,
how they're alter environments,

and how that continuous information feedback
loop is able to give us improvements.
We're able to measure the improvements and test

whether they're actually having impact
for our customers.

Awesome to see how
that loop is having an influence.
What is the future hold for Vodafone NZ?

Sure, so I touched on at the start
the main channels we're dealing with
with synchronous chat and synchronous phone.

Adding to that in the future we will be adding
asynchronous chat through social accounts,

through WhatsApp, through Apple Business Chat,
through email, and SMS.

This will enhance our reach
and get our product into

where the customers are most comfortable dealing
with our solution.

Kris, thank you
for sharing your architecture with us.

It's really nice to see how Vodafone
NZ is taking a customer first, agent first,

team lead first, developer first approach,
to enhance the user experience
for the product that they've created.

Again, thank you
for sharing your architecture with us.
Thanks Viral, it's been a pleasure.

And thank you for watching
'This is My Architecture'.
